Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: It’s Thursday evening, and my phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” Every week, without fail, I check in, listen to Dad’s stories, and reassure Mom that I’m eating well. They look forward to these calls, and so do I—usually. But tonight, my headset is still warm from hours of cold calls. It’s the last day of the quarter, and my manager’s voice echoes in my head: “We need three more sales, or we all lose our bonuses.” My team’s counting on me. I glance at the clock—if I call my parents now, I’ll miss the prime hour for closing deals. If I keep dialing prospects, I’ll break my promise to my parents, who wait by the phone every Thursday. My stomach knots as I stare at my phone, torn between the comfort of family and the pressure of work, knowing someone will be disappointed no matter what I choose.
